title: Indian Prime Minister Modi skipped an election rally in Kashmir, where critics dispute India's claim of integration into the country.
content:
**Summary:**

Prime Minister Modi's party, BJP, is not running in Kashmir's elections for the first time since 1996. Local parties like the National Conference and People's Democratic Party are competing against each other but are united against BJP.

Analysts and opposition parties believe BJP skipped the election because they know they won't win. The party claims to have brought peace to Kashmir, but residents say discontent and alienation remain.

Kashmir is divided between India and Pakistan, and both countries claim the entire region. India accuses Pakistan of supporting Kashmiri rebels, while Pakistan denies this.

In 2022, the government redrew constituency boundaries in Kashmir, adding mostly Hindu voters from Jammu to Muslim-majority Anantnag. Opposition parties say this was done to give BJP an advantage. However, BJP says it makes the constituencies more representative.
summary: In a first since 1996, the BJP avoids contesting in Kashmir due to local opposition alliance against BJP's Hindu nationalist stance, despite Modi's claims of normalcy post-2019 status removal.

title: US temporarily stopped sending some weapons to Israel amid clashes near the Gaza border.
content:
**Israel-Gaza Conflict Update**

**Fighting in Rafah**

* Hamas and Israeli troops are fighting on the outskirts of Rafah in Gaza.
* US has stopped a shipment of bombs that Israel could use for a full-scale attack.

**Ceasefire Talks**

* US believes a new ceasefire proposal from Hamas could lead to a breakthrough.
* Talks are resuming in Cairo.
* US has delayed a shipment of weapons to Israel in response to the expected attack on Rafah.

**Israeli Offensive**

* Israeli forces have seized a border crossing with Egypt, cutting off aid.
* Israeli tank fire has hit a building in Rafah.
* Hamas, Islamic Jihad, and Fatah are fighting against Israeli forces.
* Israel has ordered civilians to move to a "humanitarian zone."

**Aid and Casualties**

* Aid supplies are running low in Gaza due to closed crossings.
* Around 200 patients have been evacuated from a hospital in Rafah.
* Israeli offensive has killed thousands of Palestinians.
summary: Hamas said it was battling Israeli troops on the outskirts of the Gaza Strip’s crowded southern city of Rafah on Wednesday after a US official said Washington had halted a shipment of powerful bombs that Israel could use in a full-scale assault.The United States, which is seeking to stave off an Israeli invasion of Rafah, said it believes a revised Hamas ceasefire proposal may lead to a breakthrough in an impasse in negotiations, with talks resuming in Cairo on Wednesday.A senior US official said President Joe Biden’s administration paused a shipment of weapons to Israel last week in an apparent response to the expected Rafah offensive. The White House and Pentagon declined to comment.The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Washington had carefully reviewed the delivery of weapons that might be used in Rafah, and as a result paused a shipment consisting of 1,800 2,000-lb bombs and 1,700 500-lb bombs.This would be the first such delay since the Biden administration offered its “ironclad” support to Israel after Hamas’ Oct. 7 attack. Washington is Israel’s closest ally and main weapons supplier.A senior Israeli official declined to confirm the report, asking not to be named: “If we have to fight with our fingernails, then we’ll do what we have to do,” the source said. A military spokesperson said any disagreements were resolved in private.Israeli forces seized the main border crossing between Gaza and Egypt in Rafah on Tuesday, cutting off a vital aid route.Residents and officials said Rafah’s city council building was hit by Israeli tank fire on Tuesday and caught fire.“The streets of the city echo with the cries of innocent lives lost, families torn apart, and homes reduced to rubble. We stand on the brink of a humanitarian catastrophe of unprecedented proportions,” Rafah’s mayor, Ahmed Al-Sofi, said in an appeal to the international community to intervene.The Israeli military said on Wednesday it had uncovered Hamas infrastructure in several locations in eastern Rafah and its troops were conducting targeted raids on the Gaza side of the Rafah crossing and airstrikes across the Gaza Strip.It has told civilians to go to an “expanded humanitarian zone” in al-Mawasi, some 20 km (12 miles) away.Armed groups of Hamas, Islamic Jihad and Fatah said in separate statements that gunfights continued in the central Gaza Strip, while residents of northern Gaza reported heavy Israeli tank shelling against eastern areas of Gaza City and districts.CEASEFIRE TALKSIn Cairo, all five delegations participating in talks on Tuesday - Hamas, Israel, the US, Egypt and Qatar - reacted positively to the resumption of negotiations, and meetings were expected to continue on Wednesday, two Egyptian sources said.CIA Director Bill Burns was to travel from Cairo to Israel on Wednesday to meet Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his Mossad counterpart, an Israeli government source said.Israel on Monday declared that a three-phase proposal approved by Hamas was unacceptable because terms had been watered down. White House spokesperson John Kirby said the new text presented by Hamas suggests the remaining gaps can “absolutely be closed.”The proposal included a first phase with a six-week ceasefire, an influx of aid to Gaza, the return of 33 Israeli hostages, alive or dead, and the release by Israel of 30 detained Palestinian children and women for each released Israeli hostage, according to several sources.Since a week-long ceasefire in November, the only pause so far, the two sides have been blocked by Hamas’ refusal to free more Israeli hostages without a promise of a permanent end to the conflict and Israel’s insistence on only a temporary halt.Israel’s offensive has killed 34,789 Palestinians, most of them civilians, the Gaza Health Ministry said.The war began when Hamas militants attacked Israel on Oct. 7, killing about 1,200 people and abducting 252 others, of whom 128 remain hostage in Gaza and 36 have been declared dead, according to the latest Israeli figures.Al-Sofi, Rafah’s mayor, said 1.4 million people sheltering in the city had nowhere to go. Those in eastern neighbourhoods were being told to move to the coastal al-Mawasi area “which lacks the necessities of life”, he said.Around 200 patients from Rafah’s Abu Youssef al-Najjar Hospital, in an area designated by the Israeli army as a combat zone, were forced to evacuate to the west of the city after receiving calls warning them to leave, health officials said.Israel was reopening Kerem Shalom crossing on its border with the Gaza Strip on Wednesday, a statement from the Israeli agency in charge of it said, adding aid trucks routed through from Egypt were already undergoing security inspections there.Israel had closed Kerem Shalom crossing on Sunday after Palestinian shelling nearby killed four soldiers. The United Nations had warned the closure of both the Rafah and Kerem Shalom crossings had “choked off” the two main arteries for getting aid into Gaza, with stocks low inside the enclave.

title: Book piracy is a significant issue in Nepal. Unauthorized translations and copies of foreign books are widely available.
content:
**Unauthorized Book Translations in Nepal**

Nepali book market is filled with unauthorized translations of books by famous authors like Taslima Nasrin, Steve Jobs, Bill Clinton, and Robert Kiyosaki. These translations are often inaccurate and of poor quality.

Authors and publishers often don't give permission for these translations, and they lose out on royalties. This also harms the readers, who are not getting the best possible translations.

Translating books without permission is illegal in Nepal, but the practice is widespread due to a lack of regulation and enforcement. Additionally, the government's decision to impose a 10% tax on book imports has led to an increase in piracy.

Unauthorized translations have become so common that publishers can even assign ISBN numbers to their books, which is illegal. The government, publishers, and authors need to work together to control this issue, protect intellectual property, and promote a healthy book publishing industry in Nepal.
summary: Unauthorized translations of popular international books are rampant in Nepal's market, with authors such as Taslima Nasrin, Steve Jobs, and Robert Kiyosaki being major victims, leading to concerns about the quality of translations and copyright infringement.

title: Young people from a region with a history of Maoist insurgency in India are facing challenges and economic hardship, leading to their disillusionment and migration to cities in search of opportunities.
content:
Youths from Rukum East are illegally traveling to the United States (US) despite the risks. Many have been deported and lost millions of rupees in the process.

The once Maoist "base area" of Tak village has been hit hard, with many families losing money and even loved ones who died while trying to reach the US.

The youths are desperate to escape poverty and are taking out large loans at high interest rates to fund their journeys.

Agents are exploiting this situation and charging exorbitant fees for illegal travel and refugee status.

Despite the dangers and financial losses, many youths are still trying to reach the US, believing it is their only hope for a better life.

The lack of jobs and economic opportunities in Nepal, as well as the failure of local and political authorities to address the issue, are contributing factors to the problem.
summary: Bharat Budha, chair of Putha Uttarganga Rural Municipality’s ward 10, knows that many youths from his village have made it to the United States via ‘tallo bato’—backdoor route—and that many are still on the way. He also knows that eight of them have been deported from the country and that they have lost a cumulative Rs45 million in the process. The deported youths say that they returned home empty-handed after facing unspeakable ordeals and lost Rs6 million each on average.The Tak village in Rukum East—a close-knit settlement of 425 houses—was considered the Maoists’ ‘base area’ during the insurgency. Village youths who reached the US through illegal routes and got deported have lost an estimated Rs40 million. The number of those who returned without completing the journey and the amount they lost remain unknown.To get to the US, the youths have taken loans at up to 36 percent interest per annum from their relatives and village landowners. In Tak village, at least one person each from half of the households has gone abroad, Budha said. “Youths started going to America about six-seven years ago,” he said. “If they could gather enough money, the whole village would try to go to the US.” Budha’s own son had reached the US illegally in 2017, spending Rs3.2 million.During the insurgency, outsize slogans of revolution would adorn the walls of houses in the village. Hoping for a better life, people from all walks of life helped out the Maoists. But now, village youths are paying the agents to illegally get to the US—a country that the Maoists used to call their ‘enemy’, an ‘imperialistic force’. This has cost the Tak village much and in multiple ways.Death of a dreamSome of the deported youths have chosen to flee the village altogether, burdened with debt and creditors’ pressure. At least five such families have already left, said a resident. The family of Ram Budha was one of them. On April 28, 2015, Ram, who had returned to Nepal after working in Malaysia for eight years, took the illegal route to the US. He travelled through arduous trails for months and finally arrived in the country. Upon reaching the country, he was detained and had to stay at the detention camp for 27 months. When his refugee application was rejected, he was deported to Nepal in mid-December 2019. He lost Rs4.5 million in the process. He now owes over Rs6 million to creditors. “After the creditors began to put pressure on me, I couldn’t live in the village peacefully,” said Ram, who currently runs a vegetable farm in Tarakeshwar, Kathmandu.While those who got to the US through illegal routes and fortunately got refugee status there narrate their stories with pride, those who have been deported or returned from half-way have tragic tales to tell.Nanda Kala Gharti, who lives in a small stone house on the upper flank of Tak village, spends her days in melancholy. Her husband, Dhanlal, had chosen to take the illegal route to the US, and Nanda Kala, a mother of four, is living with the repercussions of his decision. Dhanlal had got into the US after a six-month long arduous journey and was detained immediately. He had to spend four years in the detention camp, before he was deported to Nepal. He had already lost Rs6 million.Nanda Kala said they now have an insurmountable crisis in their hands. Pointing to her son, she exclaimed, “When will he grow up, go abroad and pay back the loans!”Dhanlal himself tried to go to Croatia once and spent 15 days in Kathmandu for the process. But after he was turned down, he returned home dejected. “Now we will submit the passport to another agent [for Dhanlal’s trip abroad],” Nanda Kala said. “There’s no point staying here.”Stories that echo each otherThe situation in Sisne Rural Municipality is similar to that of Putha Uttarganga. Here, one can hear plenty of stories of those who have tried to go to the US and those who are fighting refugee cases there. Krishna Regmi, chair of the rural municipality, personally knows seven people who have been deported from the US.Gangaram Khadka, a resident of Sisne-3, runs a bee and chicken farm. Like other young men in his village, Khadka had headed off to the US via an illegal route on 27 March, 2018. He had reached the US via the New Delhi-Moscow-Barcelona-Bogota-Panama-Costa Rica-Nicaragua-Honduras-Guatemala-Mexico route. When he finally arrived in the US, he was detained and had to spend 11 months in detention. He was deported on 15 March, 2019. He had handed over Rs3.2 millions to the agent and spent Rs2 million to fight the case to become a refugee. “It’s not possible for me to pay back the loan while working in Nepal,” he said. “I aim to pay back some interest and head off abroad again.”For six months after Khadka was deported, he had anxiety and headache, he said, adding the three people from his village who were deported like him are also struggling with their mental health.Tikaram Pun, a 40-year-old resident of Bohora village in Musikot-4, is also haunted by his past journey. In September 2017, he reached the US after crossing 17 countries with the help of organised human traffickers. Of the 41 people in his group, 31 were from Rukum East and Rukum West, he said. Pun, who was detained on arrival in the US, spent 24 months in a detention camp. His refugee application was also refused and so he was deported along with eight other Nepalis. “When I returned, I started having mental health problems. I still suffer from them,” he said. Pun is under pressure from creditors and relatives to pay back the Rs9.2 million loan he had taken for the task.Those who died on the wayA group of 10 Bangladeshis and seven Nepalis, including Rupak Bohora of Bafikot-3 in Rukum West, were on a mission to reach Costa Rica through Colombia, Caribbean Coast, Capuragana and Panama. But while they were crossing a sea, their boat capsized. As many as 12 died in the incident, including six Nepalis. Rupak’s wife, Geeta, learned about the incident only after six days, on 25 June, 2021.“I still don’t know what exactly happened,” said Geeta, who had been married off at age 19 and is now a mother of two daughters. The only thing she knows is that Rupak has died and she is now all alone. And that she has Rs5 million in loan taken for Rupak’s trip. She showed a picture of her husband on her phone to this scribe and said, “I only have memories.”Lack of political will and legal remediesThe concrete bridge over Chewang river is on the edge of Tak village. On the walls of the bridge are paintings of political theorists like Marx, Engels, Lenin, Stalin and Mao, and the iconic slogan, ‘Workers of the world, unite!’, below them. But the slogan appears to be at odds with life in the village. Given the phenomenon of illegal travels to the US through the help of organised human traffickers, the whole village appears to be emptying. Neither the local governments are concerned about the phenomenon nor are the political parties paying attention.Puniraj Gharti, chair of Putha Uttarganga Rural Municipality, said though the trend is worrying, there’s nothing he can do. “How could we stop them from making the trip when they are struggling to make a living in the village?” he said.Krishna Regmi, chair of Sisne Rural Municipality, said that the vicious cycle of poverty started after marijuana farming was banned in the country. Then the Maoist insurgency added to the woe, forcing youths to migrate. The signing of the peace agreement in 2006 didn’t herald any change in the economy either and youths are struggling to get jobs. Organised human traffickers are cashing in on this sorry state of affairs, Regmi said. “Meter byajis [usurious lenders] are also promoting this phenomenon,” he added.The phenomenon is equally rife in Dang’s Tulsipur and Ghorahi. Ramesh Kumar Pandey, chair of Ghorai-15, says that even though many heading to the US are swindled, no complaints are filed at the ward office. “Only those who attempt to go to Saudi Arabia or Qatar file the complaints,” he said.One can infer from Pandey’s statements that the families of such illegal travellers don’t want to publicise the ordeals of their family members. On the one hand, agents threaten them to not publicise the issue; on the other, they fear they themselves would be punished by law.According to the Anti-Human Trafficking Bureau, as many as 178 Nepalis, including 174 men, have been deported from the US in the five fiscal years after 2018-19. Of them, the highest 49 are from Rukum while 37 are from Dang. The data doesn’t include those who returned after making it to the half-way or those who have been fighting the legal battle in the US for refugee status. But this data is enough to show that many such youths are from the ‘base areas’ of the Maoist insurgency.SSP Jeevan Shrestha, chief of the bureau, said that data on the number of such victims and the amounts they have spent is hard to collect since complaints are rarely filed with the police. “This is human trafficking but for a lack of law, we are still compelled to launch the cases as per Human Trafficking and Transportation (Control) Act 2074 BS,” Shrestha said. “The Act provides a maximum penalty of Rs250,000 for the offenders and 50 percent of that as compensation to the victims.” Without specific law, police also invoke the theft and organised crime act to punish the offenders, he added.On the one hand, police receive no complaints; on the other, the phenomenon sees no control.Bhaskar Gautam, a political scientist, says the rise in cases of human trafficking in the insurgency’s ‘base areas’ is due to the political system’s abject failure.While the Maoists raised issues related to livelihood, nationalism and a new kind of democracy to fuel their war machine, after the peace process, it is livelihoods that have been hit the hardest, Gautam said. “The traditional way of life and economy took a hit during the insurgency,” he said. “Developments after the peace process also failed to address that. What sprang up was organised human trafficking.”(Mahesh KC in Rukum East and Durgalal KC in Dang contributed to this report.)This report is prepared in collaboration with the Center for Investigative Journalism-Nepal.

title: No private hospital beds for poor patients.
content:
**Hospitals Ignoring Rules to Provide Free Treatment for Needy**

Many private hospitals in Nepal are not providing free treatment to the poor, as they are supposed to do by law. This is despite the fact that the Health Facility Operation Standards-2020 requires hospitals to set aside 10% of their beds for free treatment and services.

Due to hospitals ignoring these rules, many people are struggling to afford medical care. Gyanumaya BK, a 69-year-old laborer from Pokhara, has been suffering from backaches for months and has already spent over Rs50,000 on follow-up checkups and medications.

Government regulators admit that they are not monitoring hospitals well enough, and some hospitals claim that the regulations are impractical. However, advocates for the poor say that hospitals should be held accountable for ignoring government rules that aim to help the needy.
summary: Gyanumaya BK, a low-income laborer, spent over Rs 50,000 on medical expenses after being unaware of the Health Facility Operation Standards-2020, which require private hospitals to provide free treatment to the needy, leaving her in debt and highlighting the widespread disregard for this regulation in Pokhara, Chitwan, Biratnagar, and Butwal.

title:
Nepali bureaucracy is a complex system with many levels and departments. It can be difficult to navigate, but understanding its structure can help you get things done.

The bureaucracy is divided into three main branches:
* The executive branch, which includes the prime minister and cabinet, is responsible for carrying out laws and policies.
* The legislative branch, which includes the parliament, is responsible for making laws.
* The judicial branch, which includes the courts, is responsible for interpreting and enforcing laws.

Within each branch, there are many different departments and agencies. Each department has its own specific responsibilities. For example, the Ministry of Home Affairs is responsible for law enforcement, while the Ministry of Finance is responsible for managing the country's finances.

To get something done through the bureaucracy, you will need to know which department is responsible for the issue you are facing. You can then contact the department directly or go through a local government office.

Here are some tips for dealing with the Nepali bureaucracy:

* Be patient and persistent. It can take time to get things done through the bureaucracy, but don't give up.
* Be polite and respectful. Even if you are frustrated, it is important to be polite and respectful to government officials.
* Be prepared to provide documentation. You will often be asked to provide documentation to support your request. Make sure you have all the necessary documents before you submit your request.
* Be aware of corruption. Corruption is a problem in Nepal, so it is important to be aware of it and to take steps to protect yourself from it.
content:
Nepali bureaucracy is considered both powerful and subservient to politicians.

This is because bureaucrats have gained more power since the end of the monarchy, due to laws protecting them from political influence. They can now stand up to politicians when their decisions are unconstitutional.

However, this added power has also led to negative outcomes, such as bureaucrats colluding with politicians for personal gain. Reforms are needed to address these issues, such as ending party-based trade unions and linking promotions to performance.
summary: Post-monarchy in Nepal, the bureaucracy has strengthened, leading to contradictory macro-narratives about its power: simultaneous subservience to politicians and ability to challenge them, due to increased options for bureaucrats in resisting, maintaining status quo, or colluding with political establishment.

title:
Massing of education refers to the crowding of students into large classrooms, often with limited resources and support. It can lead to:

* Reduced individual attention
* Lack of personalized learning
* Overwhelmed teachers
* Decreased student engagement
* Lower academic outcomes
content:
**Mass Higher Education: Its Rise and Impact**

After World War II, the idea of making higher education available to everyone became popular, leading to a rapid increase in the number of colleges and universities. This expansion was driven by a desire to create social equality and boost economic growth.

However, this growth has come at a cost. To make higher education more accessible, schools have lowered admission standards and reduced the difficulty of coursework. This has resulted in a decline in the quality of education and the readiness of graduates for jobs that require critical thinking and innovation.

Despite these concerns, the push for mass higher education continues, fueled by calls for lifelong learning and the promise of economic benefits. However, it is important to remember that the primary goal of higher education should be to equip students with the knowledge and skills to contribute to society, not just to meet economic needs.
summary: Post-WWII "mass higher education" is a result of neoliberal policies emphasizing rapid expansion and privatization of HE, driven by economic interests and fueled by the notion of "human capital," leading to a global crisis of low standards and a decline in original research.

title: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is likely to run for a third term in office in 2024. He has a strong political base and a loyal following. content:

title: Toilets for all refers to the provision of accessible and clean toilets for everyone, regardless of gender, disability, or other factors. It aims to address the lack of adequate sanitation facilities and promote public health and hygiene for all.
content:
**Gender-Inclusive Toilets**

Activists and LGBTQ+ people want toilets that are not just for men or women but also for people who don't fit into those categories.

**Benefits:**

* Allows everyone to use a toilet that matches their gender identity
* Reduces discrimination and harassment
* Promotes equality and safety

**Importance:**

* Transgender and non-binary people face problems using traditional male or female toilets.
* Studies show that LGBT+ students often avoid toilets due to safety concerns.

**Nepal's Progress:**

* Nepal is promoting gender equality and building inclusive toilets.
* Kathmandu plans to build 10 new public toilets for queer and disabled people.

**Challenges:**

* Not enough gender-inclusive toilets in Nepal.
* Even with inclusive toilets, LGBTQ+ people may still face harassment.

**Solution:**

* Build gender-inclusive toilets with proper facilities (e.g., good design, running water, tactile pavements).
* Educate people about disability, sexuality, and gender diversity to create inclusive spaces.
summary: Activists worldwide urge for gender-inclusive toilets breaking the gender binary, with Nepal promoting gender-friendly efforts, and challenges remain in ensuring safety and inclusivity for transgender and non-binary individuals.

title: Unity is strength, division is weakness.
content:
**Coalition Split in Nepal**

Rival political groups have split a smaller party in the ruling coalition, allegedly to stop a plan to overthrow the government. This is the latest example of frequent party breakups and mergers in Nepal.

The split in the Janata Samajbadi Party Nepal is blamed on former leader Upendra Yadav trying to form an alliance with the opposition.

Prime Minister Pushpa Kamal Dahal and other leaders noticed this and split Yadav's party to prevent the plan. Most of the party members stayed in the ruling coalition.

These splits are common in Nepal, especially among parties representing Madhes, a region with marginalized communities. The breakup-merger process is often driven by power struggles and personal conflicts, rather than ideological differences.

These splits weaken important political movements and make people lose faith in parties. They also reduce the presence of diverse political forces in Nepal, which is important for a vibrant society.
summary: Nepal's ruling coalition splits again, with the Janata Samajbadi Party Nepal dividing over alleged plans to topple the government and join the opposition.

title: Doing something together
content: Prime Minister Dahal wants to investigate fraud in cooperative banks. He says it is a serious problem and wants to form a parliamentary committee to investigate. He also says that the investigation should not target any specific person, including Home Minister Lamichhane, who is accused of embezzlement. However, the main opposition party, the Nepali Congress, does not trust Dahal and believes he is trying to protect Lamichhane. They have vowed to continue blocking parliament until the investigation is launched. To avoid this, Dahal must convince the Congress that the investigation will be fair and that no one will be shielded from investigation, even Lamichhane.
summary: Prime Minister Dahal proposed a parliamentary probe into fraudulent co-operative practices, but the Nepali Congress expressed skepticism over the potential shielding of Home Minister Lamichhane from investigation.

title: Expect difficulties in the coming two months due to recent fires.
content:
**Fire Incidents in Nepal: Causes and Solutions**

Many fires in Nepal have caused loss of life and property. The National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Authority explains why:

**Causes:**

* Lack of rainfall, leading to dry vegetation
* High temperatures and strong winds
* Accumulation of dry leaves and debris from previous winters
* Stubble burning by farmers
* Empty and overgrown settlements

**Solutions:**

* Increased rainfall and reduced temperatures
* Training people to fight fires, especially in community forest groups
* Using portable fire pumps, which are easy to use in remote areas
* Developing rescue equipment and helicopters
* Raising awareness about the dangers of stubble burning
* Conducting risk assessments and strengthening local governments' response capabilities
summary: Numerous destructive fire incidents in Nepal have caused fatalities and widespread property loss in recent weeks, primarily due to insufficient rainfall, soaring temperatures, high winds, and accumulated forest litter.

title: Nepal offers equal opportunities and a fair business environment for all investors, regardless of nationality or size, to encourage investment and economic growth.
content:

Nepal is hosting an investment summit to attract foreign investment. The government will present investment opportunities and try to get investors interested.

Nepal has learned from past summits and is working to make it more attractive for investors.

title: Direct election of Prime Minister and Chief Ministers could solve the problem of political instability and confusion.
content:
**Political Bickering Hinders Provincial Governments**

Political parties are competing aggressively to form provincial governments, causing public frustration. Leaders are blaming the electoral system for political instability, but political culture and personal ambition are the real culprits.

**Mixed Electoral System under Scrutiny**

The electoral system combines proportional representation (PR) with direct election. Some argue that it promotes corruption and instability due to its lack of clear majorities. Others believe that it has increased representation for marginalized groups.

**PR vs. FPTP: A Debate**

The first-past-the-post (FPTP) system is seen as favorable to certain groups, while the PR system provides more representation for women, dalits, and indigenous communities. Leaders have misused the PR system, selecting unqualified candidates and selling seats for profit.

**Direct Election of Executives Proposed**

To address instability, a political analyst suggests electing the Prime Minister and Chief Ministers directly, similar to the system in local governments. This would remove the influence of political parties and provide stability.

**Provinces: A Burden or Opportunity?**

Provinces are accused of financial burden and corruption. However, they were created to address Nepal's centralized governance and promote inclusivity. Poor governance and lack of reforms have contributed to their failure.

**Public Sentiment in Madhesh Province**

People in Madhesh Province are dissatisfied with the lack of progress in the federal system and the continued dominance of elite groups. They question the benefits of provinces.

**Rise of New Parties**

The Janamat Party and Nagarik Unmukti Party emerged in the 2022 elections, representing Madhesh discrimination and Tharu community interests respectively. They challenge the old Madheshi parties and advocate for good governance.
summary: As political parties engage in power struggles and blame the electoral system for instability, analyst Tula Narayan Shah advocates for direct election of executive heads and reforms to empower provinces.

title: I support a fully proportional representation system with a 5% threshold.
content:
**Proposed Electoral Reform in Nepal**

Nepali Congress leaders are urging a change in the mixed electoral system, arguing that it leads to political instability. They believe the two largest parties (Congress and UML) should collaborate to reform the system.

Former election commissioner Neel Kantha Uprety believes any electoral system's success depends on its users and must align with the country's unique circumstances. Nepal's mixed system, introduced in 2007, was designed to ensure representation for historically marginalized groups.

However, political leaders have misused the PR system by promoting their close associates, leading to anomalies. Experts suggest a fully PR system with provisions to prevent manipulation and ensure true inclusivity.

Other proposals include increasing the threshold for PR representation and allocating certain constituencies for marginalized groups, but these are considered less effective.

Uprety advocates for a fully PR system with a raised threshold, which would reduce costs and increase inclusivity.

Allowing Nepalis abroad to vote is technically feasible but considered politically inconvenient for leaders due to the unpredictable nature of overseas votes.
summary: Nepali Congress and CPN-UML suggest electoral reform to ensure political stability, with mixed reactions and discussions on past anomalies and potential improvements in the mixed electoral system.

title: Muluki Ain is a legal code that guides the legal system in a particular country.
content: The Muluki Ain, a legal code created in 1854, aimed to establish a rule of law and modernize the legal system. It recognized the caste system as part of Nepal's social structure but also called for reforms to address its injustices. The code covered all aspects of life, from criminal punishments to social customs. While it was based on traditional values, it also acknowledged the need for change.
summary: The 1854 Muluki Ain translated by Heidelberg University rationalized the legal structure and codified principles of law throughout Nepal, recognizing the rule of law, while acknowledging the caste system's presence and expressing intent for future reforms.

title: chhaupadi-persists
content: While feminine issues are addressed every now and then, not everything is taken seriously, and the unspoken issues go unnoticed. Here, I’m not only addressing the horrendous issue of Chhaupadi itself but also speaking of those women and girls who fall prey to this absurd menstrual practice.Ever thought what travelling back in time would feel like? Many in Nepal do not have to imagine, as such old and evil practises continue to occur in the 21st century!Chhaupadi is a flawed tradition connected to the taboo surrounding menstruation that prohibits Hindu menstruators from participating in normal family activities while on their period, as they are considered impure. Although it is said to be practised in the rural part of the country, it does exist in urban areas, too. Going back to its roots, we could perhaps rationalise that women were asked to stay cautious when menstruating because humans were closely surrounded by wildlife. The stench of blood during their period may have made them more vulnerable to attacks from these animals. But even this absurd line of thought doesn't make much sense anymore. The practise was made illegal in 2005, but cases related to it were reported as recent as 2019. News headlines vouched for fatalities on this account. But why are there such trivial punishments for such an offence? Shouldn’t the punishments be rethought to strongly discourage Chhaupadi altogether?Moreover, the reported cases are just the tip of the iceberg. The more you look into it, there are bound to be cases that have gone unreported because nothing immediately tragic occurred. This letter is a call for all of us to come together to fight this social plague. While the legal implications of such an offence are ambiguous, let's collectively decide that the societal implications of it will be grave. Let's refuse to accept such atrocities for our mothers, sisters and, above all, ourselves.Gauri Tandon, via email
